summary_reasoning: The report demonstrates solid analytical depth with clear causal mechanisms and explicit, quantified assumptions tied to drivers of AXP’s earnings and valuation. It links performance to business model advantages and macro levers (e.g., premium customer spend, rate environment, funding mix), and benchmarks forward assumptions to recent history. Examples include: “have underpinned these gains” (closed-loop/premium mix), “expanding deposit base and disciplined expense control” (margin support), “Rising interest rates extend revenue on loan balances” (rate sensitivity on NII), “now nearly 70% of funding” (funding mix quantification), “We assume 500–700 basis points in annual interest income lifts” (explicit driver assumption), and “WACC ~8%” / “Terminal growth ~3%” (valuation inputs). Forecasts are tied to drivers with quantified ranges (“10-15% EPS CAGR”), and historical benchmarking is used (2023–2024 growth and margins). However, the analysis lacks quantified scenario/sensitivity work: there is no modeling of credit losses, deposit beta, or rate-path impacts on NIM/earnings, and no valuation sensitivity to WACC/terminal growth. Counterpoints are discussed qualitatively (“Uncertainty stems from trade policy”), but without stress tests. Actionable implications are present (shares near FVE, risk of multiple compression), yet they would be stronger with conditional triggers and ranges. Overall, strong mechanisms and quantified assumptions earn a Good rating, constrained by the absence of explicit scenario and sensitivity analysis.

missing_mechanisms: Interest income lift basis (bps) not clearly defined
Fee growth > NII lacks merchant discount rate mechanism
unsupported_assumptions: WACC ~8% without peer COE or rate benchmark
lack_of_sensitivity: No rate path or deposit beta scenarios
